snippet: Despite rules empowering shareholders to rein in soaring pay packages, few have chosen to do so, perhaps because of a rising stock market.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column examines list of 200 highest-paid American chief executives, noting that average pay has increased 12 percent in five years since passage of Dodd-Frank law; observes that rules forcing companies to let investors vote on executive pay practices have had surprisingly little effect.
lead_paragraph: Despite rules empowering shareholders to rein in soaring pay packages, few have chosen to do so, perhaps because of a rising stock market.

headline.print_headline: Shareholders’ Votes Have Done Little to Curb the Festivities
